instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.SMC_LRESET_L: What is SMC_LRESET_L? SMC_LRESET_L is a typo of SMC_RESET_L. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB activity/No Boot
threads.message:
Board had a tiny bit of corrosion on <CHIP>U3540</CHIP>, replaced that and now it gets stuck around 0.360A steady no loop.

VCORE 1.8V steady, no LIO flex or SMC bypass same thing.

Already tried:
Clean known good BIOS
Raballed CPU

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB activity/No Boot
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean J6100, if needed.
Also check all resistors in the LPC lines, between SMC and PCH.
<SIGNAL>SMC_LRESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB activity/No Boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LRESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
Check all those resistors
Replaced SMC just in case, same result all around.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB activity/No Boot
threads.message:
You may have bad CPU.
Or possible bad solders underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No USB activity/No Boot
threads.message: Ok some feedback, I reballed the CPU same problem, I have become proficient at doing this now, since that is the case and I have some of this boards here with shorted PCH or CPU I decided to do a CPU swap and same problem, so it is a bad CPU indeed, thanks a lot!
